claim: If you swallow gum, nothing will happen to you.

supporting.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, causing no harm.

attacks.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, causing no harm.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require swallowing very large quantities.
Gum may contain artificial sweeteners or other additives that can cause digestive discomfort.
Most gum additives are approved as safe for consumption in small quantities.

supporting.text: Swallowing gum does not lead to intestinal blockages unless consumed in extremely large quantities.

attacks.text: Swallowing gum does not lead to intestinal blockages unless consumed in extremely large quantities.
Even small amounts of swallowed gum can accumulate over time, potentially causing blockages in children or individuals with digestive issues.
Medical studies show that gum passes through the digestive system intact in the vast majority of cases, even in children.
Gum can adhere to other undigested materials in the intestines, increasing blockage risk regardless of quantity.
The human digestive system is designed to pass indigestible materials, and isolated cases of blockages are extremely rare.

supporting.text: The human digestive system cannot break down the synthetic polymers in gum, so it is excreted unchanged.

attacks.text: The human digestive system cannot break down the synthetic polymers in gum, so it is excreted unchanged.
While gum is excreted unchanged, swallowing large amounts can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and typically require swallowing very large quantities at once.
Some people may experience mild digestive discomfort or nausea after swallowing gum, even if it passes through unchanged.
Digestive discomfort from gum is usually psychosomatic or due to other ingredients, not the gum base itself.

supporting.text: Medical consensus states that swallowing small amounts of gum is harmless and does not require intervention.

attacks.text: Medical consensus states that swallowing small amounts of gum is harmless and does not require intervention.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require ingestion of very large quantities.
Gum contains artificial sweeteners and preservatives that may cause mild digestive discomfort in sensitive individuals.
The digestive discomfort caused by gum ingredients is typically minor and temporary, not requiring medical attention.

supporting.text: Gum does not stick to the intestines or stomach lining, contrary to common myths.

attacks.text: Gum does not stick to the intestines or stomach lining, contrary to common myths.
While gum doesn't stick, it can cause blockages if swallowed in large quantities, especially in children.
Cases of gum causing blockages are extremely rare and usually involve pre-existing digestive issues.
Gum contains indigestible polymers that can accumulate in the digestive tract over time.
The human digestive system can pass small amounts of indigestible material without issue.
